entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin sententia feeling, opinion, from *sentent-, *sentens, irregular present participle of sentire to feel sense

def.dt: :opinion
:a conclusion given on request or reached after deliberation
:judgment 2a
:one formally pronounced by a court or judge in a criminal proceeding and specifying the punishment to be inflicted upon the convict
:the punishment so imposed serve out a sentence
:maxim saw

:a word, clause, or phrase or a group of clauses or phrases forming a syntactic unit which expresses an assertion, a question, a command, a wish, an exclamation, or the performance of an action, that in writing usually begins with a capital letter and concludes with appropriate end punctuation, and that in speaking is distinguished by characteristic patterns of stress, pitch, and pauses
:a mathematical or logical statement (as an equation or a proposition) in words or symbols
:period 2b
:to impose a sentence on
:to cause to suffer something sentenced these most primitive cultures to extinction E. W. Count
:a word, phrase, or clause that usually has in speech the intonation of a sentence but lacks the grammatical structure usually found in the sentences of formal and especially written composition
:the manner in which stresses are distributed on the syllables of words assembled into sentences called also sentence accent
:a sentence condemning a convicted defendant to death
:an affliction or a situation that is considered to be fatal
:a prognosis of death
:a sentence in which the principal clause comes first and subordinate modifiers or trailing elements follow
:a statement (as in mathematics) that contains at least one blank or unknown and that becomes true or false when the blank is filled or a quantity is substituted for the unknown
:a usually complex sentence that has no subordinate or trailing elements following its principal clause (as in “yesterday while I was walking down the street, I saw him”)
:a sentence containing two or more clauses not connected by the correct conjunction or punctuation
:a sentence that states the main thought of a paragraph or of a larger unit of discourse and is usually placed at or near the beginning
